content:
Posted: October 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								Kenshi, Kenshi, Kenshi you are like a mistress on the side of real life. I wish I could put more time into you but things (work, child, fiance) keep getting in our way of eternal love. I know I keep promising that I can just leave them and we could spend the rest of our days frollicking in meadows of beautiful flowers, desert landscapes and the occasional cannibal lair. I know we could be happy together taking on adversary and even build a place we can call home from nothing but the goods we traded from our previous lives. I feel like I am at war with some holy group telling me my feelings are false and us being together serves a dark purpose. I shall enter you and end up leaving just before we get to the fun stuff while I am seen by prying eyes behind my back and whispering voices telling me this is not real and I shouldnt be spending my spare time with you. I hope you can understand that I am torn in every direction but yours as I know you do not judge me for letting you sit idle while I create false memories with people who will never understand me like you do. Maybe someone else will pick you up and have the wonderful times we have had, I would be sad to see you with someone else but happy that you get to have the adventures we have spent those dark nights dreaming of together. Kenshi if this is our last moments, I would like you to know that I rate you a solid 8/10 although I know you are currently just a bud on a bush about to blossom into a beautiful flower and will only increase in enjoyability.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								So with the latest 20 hours added to the timer, i think i get the main idea of what the game is so far, please do pay attention to the date of this review as this is to the corrisponding version, now to give a short summary, the game has bugs, it has memory leaks, so expect to restart it a few times a day if you're limited to 4 gigs of ram like me, it looks okay in graphics department, nothing amazing, but i would rather have this then games that pose the best thing in it is the graphic's, because Beautiful looking Crap is still just crap... this game poses as a Sandbox Survival RTS that i suggest you only play if you're ready for some depressing notions of racism in it's own sense... the rest will explain but for those who just want the short review, i DO suggest this game, but to a rather... certain audience...Pros:-Customization, Most RTS games just give you a set number of looks and style and that's just it, while this game HAS that, you can make "Your" characters look however you want, 4 races, plenty of attributes from facial to physical body, this game let's you make your team as unique as you desire.-No levels, Just skill and survival, and this can be an issue in some cases, the game has added a hunger meter (and also a mod to remove it for beginners, just look through the workshop.) and note, most things you fight one on one, WILL kill you, now note, this game has factions, and there far, other people will join the fight, if it's against you however, you may be rather... dead, in the next few seconds, you're NOT the chosen one, you're a new person in this harsh world, and you have to EARN your power the obvious ways, running around will make you run faster, carrying heavy stuff will make you stronger, taking hits will make you more durable... if you survive.-The whole world is free to Roam... Granted if it's Not Owned... i say this because this game goes on common sense in that, if it's there, you should be able to go there, BUT it also knows that, if it's someone's home... well you're not link are you? this is'nt hyrule, this is a game that makes common sense REAL common real fast, and the open world outside towns is open for more then just combat...-Base Building, want to build a town? Have the recourses, go ahead, but make sure you know this location is ideal for what your setting up, because this game won't hold your gand in this, it's either you get ahead, just get by, or get dead... and this does have it's pros, but don't think just having a place to call your own makes you safe, if fact... it can attract some... unwanted attention-Time, and Pause, this i feel is a requirement, if a game as relentless as this DIDN'T have this? well... it's a small note, but deffinitely still worth noting, it atleast let's you think about what you're gonna do next...-No Story, Exept Your's, this game has no story mode, it's you, the world, and whatever you do in it, or don't do, and quite frankly, i feel for a game like this, is a good thing.-Multiple ways to start, start with a group, or alone, start with a dog, or as a slave, or a prisoner, it give's many ways to play, most however, WILL be a challenge...-Character Value, a jack of all trades is a master of none, not to say you can't train all character's in everything, but you'll be spending a few months to try with just a couple characters... overall, this game makes you pick and choose of your own will what person will do what, by this i mean, you can have everyone fight with no healer's or anyone building a bse, BUT you will die very fast, there's also permadeath... so yeah, once they die, they're gone...And now the notes i'm affriad count against this peice...Cons:-Memory Leaks, as said before, this game has issues with even the 5required specs, after 3-4 hours, 4 gigs will be lookin... bare... and the game will lag to the point it'll be getting difficult, but then again, any game that tries this WILL run into this, so this is really more of a given...-Almost Depressing, this game can be rather... Depressing, so anyone with the idea that they can feel better from playing this game when you're in a bad mood, unless you're a masochist and even then... the game has a nation, known as the "Holy Nation" that hates anything and anyone who is NOT human, and will either demand you die by them on site while sparring those who are human, or just downright kill you and the other's, it gives that sense that "Are you different? Die For it!" that makes it kinda feel difficult to...well yeah... i'm not gonna ask them to change it by any means, i just can't recommend this for a certain audience or two...And now things that are both or neither good and/or bad that are still worth noting,Nuetrals:-Early Acess, this means the game still has a way to go before saying it's finished, so if you buy this expecting a finished game, then don't buy it until the early access catagory disappears from the named tags on this game, it's still subjected to change, be updated in major ways, and over all, it's NOT a finished game...-Bugs, i place this in nuetral because, YES it's bad, BUT they WILL be fixed, and as such as of the current time, there is a bug that annoys me a bit but i beleive it can be player fixed by rebuilding nav mesh in game, in the notion that if you put your character's in a closed space, they will stop moving and if you try to move they will go to the gate you just close and open it before moving to the designated spot...Overall, yes i recomend this game, but i would like to note, Not for it's "Fun" factor, because it CAN be fun, once you find a correct way to do thing's your way, there is not a "set in Stone" correct way to do things because this is a sandbox game in it's fullest extent, but positive and negitive are in this, if you want a challenge in sandbox survival RTS, this is the best one Iv'e found, just be ready to die if you are'nt ready to fight...

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								9/10! I love this game! I am not usually one that enjoys really difficult games, but there is something about the brutal difficulty of this game that actually keeps me around. It's not like "Oh I'm not good enough..." kinda hard, it's more "I need patience and dedication to prevail" kinda hard. Basically, you start as a nobody. There are different backgrounds and starts, which I love, but I also love that the game is unforgiving. You can't just kill a group of raiders, hell, you probably can't even kill one at the start. The difficulty of this game is appropriate, and lends to the brutality of the harsh reality in which your characters live. With time, one can really succeed and have fun with this game. The challenges along the way, those are really the best part. I am a self-professed save-scummer when it comes to many games, but despite saving very often, I find myself reverting to old loads less often in this game than others. Devastating things occur to my party, but the way it happens... most of the time I just roll with it!This game features multiple ways to play, perhaps one of it's coolest features. You can get by as a lone wolf, stealing and killing while living on the run. Perhaps you yourself wish to organize a group to raid cities and farms. Maybe you wish to raise an army to do with what you please as you traverse the wastelands... in any case, you have a great deal of freedom. Basically, you can play it like a single player RPG, or more like an RTS, city builder, merchant goods management, etc. There are a few bugs, but nothing really gamebreaking. Another feature I love is that they allow you to import your old characters/buildings and so on into new versions of the game as it approaches release. There are factions in the game, and it is particularly interesting when you get involved with any of them. The factions are all unique and have interesting relationships with one another. Luring that band of bandits up to that Holy Nations City you visited may be the perfect distraction you need to rob them blind.As I mentioned before, this game is BRUTAL! My beloved characters have been enslaved, tortured/forcefully starved to death, murdered in cold blood and even eaten alive... that's right, I said EATEN ALIVE!!! Normally in games when my characters get, let's say, eaten alive, I save-scum to the save before that happened. This game encourages me to go along with the brutality though. I had a party of 17 characters or so, while running to a certain city, we were attacked. We fended off the Fog Men at first... but they kept coming... hoardes of them! All but two of my characters were left standing, carrying the wounded bodies of two other characters to safety (which in itself had my blood rushing!). As 4 of my characters got to safety, rested up and healed up, 3 were EATEN ALIVE by the Fog Men. I used what little money I had and sold everything to hire 2 more characters to join the party. We went out and managed to pick off the Fog Men that escorted our friends by setting up ambushes at tactical points. Thus far I have saved all but 1 of the captured members of my party (minus the 3 that were EATEN ALIVE), doing tactical stealth missions, solo runs and distraction assaults.Overall this game is outstanding! The aesthetic feel of it is perfect, mixing the feel of like a sumurai feudal system in the post-apocalypse. The difficulty of the game can make it a tough pill to initially swallow, but it is well worth it. The characters and races are unique (I love the Hive characters and the robotic mechanid ones, sooo cool!) Everything is fitting for the environment, nothing stands out as too high tech or too low tech. You can tell that this is the remnance of a world that once had tech, but that technology is long forgotten. There is electricity to some extent, but only what windmills and such can generate. Think Mad Max and/or Waterworld tech. Despite the brutal difficulty and the patience/sacrifice needed to succeed, I would give this game a 9/10 (as of patch 0.93 or so). I anticipate my score my go up when the game reaches full release.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2013
Early Access Review
								This is seriously one of the coolest games I have played.  The whole game is based around you and your sqaud, wait...  Scratch that...  This game hates you...  You aren't the biggest baddest guy in the world, you aren't going to be able to defeat an army by yourself, you can't do shiznit in this game...  Unless you work for it...The only way to get anywhere in this game is to work for it.  If you want to be the strongest man in the game, you have to train long and hard.  If you want a giant city, you have to get the resources, and build it by hand.One of the coolest parts about this game is the work mechanics.  Say you want one guy to be your engineer and build all the buildings and such.  Well, you aren't always going to be building things, are you?  No, so you set engineering as your permanent job, which means that if there is a building job going on, then he will do it.  And then his second job may be researching, so when there is no building going on, he is researching more buildings.This game may be an alpha, but I have played 25 hours and it seems like there is still more to research and build.  There is no sound, but the Torchlight 1 soundtrack sounds pretty good in the background!  So yeah, if you want a game where you aren't the biggest baddest guy in existence, get this game...

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								Kenshi is a fun game, but there are a few deal-breakers that I hope get future attention:-No way to recruit new guys (in the latest version) without forking over thousands at a time. There is maybe one character I've encountered that is willing to join you, and he costs 6000 in game currency.-And you're gonna need some help, because the game is irritatingly difficult when beginning. I know it is supposed to be a challenge, but the only way to level your guy is to follow around a patrol which may or may not encounter hostile groups. Even then, expect to get only a few hits in before the patrol wipes out the enemy.-Getting your character to attack is a hassle. Right clicking works some of the time. Other times you have to hold right click over an enemy and tell your character to attack him.-The staggering animation after being hit often leaves you open to another attack, which can stagger you again. Kinda lame considering that...-The punishment for losing a fight is way too severe. When you get KO'd you can be waiting upwards of 300+ seconds to have your guy wake up. After bandaging yourself, you must limp/walk to the nearest city to sleep if you don't have the materials to make a camp bed. Getting to the nearest city can take long enough, but sleeping till recovery takes waaaaaaaaaaayyyyyyyy too long considering how the rest of this recovery process goes...-If you do make a camp bed, because limping to the nearst town takes too long, I hope you don't mind spending the night with bandits or dogs, who will stand over you until you wake up. And then kill you. And if it was dogs instead of bandits, then you might as well make a new game, because they're not going anywhere after you get KO'd.-Poor optimization in its current state.A lot of people enjoy the game, and for good reason. Just be warned that you might find this game to be pretty tedious, frustrating, and possibly unplayable. I'd say to wait a while before buying.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Not to bad for a little EA. Seems my library is filling with those. Not a whole lot to do at this time except roam the waste and find new members, and sadly they dont respawn, so once you empty a bar out of potentials thats it. Otherwise its about build your base / manufacturing facility and then set out to make money. The combat is rough at first, your so overclassed, but just because your team is beaten down does not mean its over, sometimes some wake up or are just playing dead and will get up after the bad guys leave and you can save your team with them. Its also persistent in damage, if a guy has a bum leg, he will limp, and slow the party down. Having the best weapons and armor wont save you either, you can have it but if you dont know how to use it then its just a burden and for show. Lots of fun though. I dont feel like I wasted anything on this one.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								Actual Review after the first chunk of Text.I've been reading quite a few Negative Reviews about this game complaining about how it's bugged and how slow the development on this is, though I do not find this negative, especially since this game Is in Early Access and in it's Alpha Stage. People complain about games not being Bugfree while they are still in Early Access, which is meant to help the developers to improve the game by finding said bugs and reporting them to them. About the development being slow though, yes i have to agree the development is quite slow, with the game being in Early Access / Alpha for over 5 years now, though they do release updates quite regularly most of the time. well now that this rant is over on to the Actual Review.Kenshi is a Squad Based Open World Role playing Game that is currently in it's Alpha (for over 5 years now).The Game in it's current version has already quite a lot to offer, especially with some of the bigger updates still coming up. The Development on this game can be quite slow since it is being produced by a small Team consisting of 6 Actual members and a few Volunteers and Freelancers.Positives about the Game:+ You currently have quite a Huge map that you can explore and build your base on with more and different Land to be released in a future update.+ You aren't god in this game, you are a basic human (or group of humans) that has to survive in the desert (maybe other places in later updates), not more, not less.+ The game is actively being Developed even if it may be slow, the game has been receiving updates for over 5 years now so I'll doubt that the studio has any plans on abandoning it.+ Has great music (not too much different music but great music)Negatives:- You won't get a full on Role Playing feel yet as the game is still in development.- A bit hard to get into at first- Kinda slow development though i don't blame them, I have enough respect for them for even trying to make a game like this.- Obviously, you will experience Bugs since it's in Early Access.Final Verdict:This Game is already great and shows potential to become one of my favorite Squad Based RPGs. If you are a fan of games like these go ahead and buy it, but be aware that the Game is still in Early Access / Alpha which means you won't get a full on "Finished Game" experience. Early Access is here to help Developers find bugs and help them find ideas not for actually playing the game early. So if you want to help the Development (even if it is quite slow sometimes) go ahead and get it. But if you want a full game experience wait until the Game gets out of Early Access somewhen.

content:
Posted: January 28
Early Access Review
								Used to be my favorite game of all time.  Now I find the map & content to be cluttered.  It used to be about samurai, and now it's about something I don't understand yet.  The game expanded too much on too many different things & themes at once, which took away its main appeal to me.  If you're looking for a samurai game, then this isn't it unfortunately.  I bought it when it was a game about swordsman traveling the land making a name for their self.  Now there's monsters, the map is too big, overpowered NPC's in large massive groups and despawning NPC's.  I feel like every single update for the past year or so, has not made the game any better, if anything.. all of it feels random to me.  Why are there monsters?  How do they make the game any better?  What's the point in the map being so large when the game insists that you build a base and just turtle your entire playthrough.  Things like being a merchant is really dumb now with how large the map is and so on.  Seems like the only ideal way to play this game is to turtle at a base, and bait enemies into your harpoon nest.  Game used to be more of a "do whatever you want" now it's just a RTS survival game.  Having enemies in a massive group (like 20+) teaches you that you should be prioritizing getting the largest squad, not attacking anyone, and baiting bandits into them for the first 20+ hours.  NPC's need to be more scattered, not only are these NPC's capable of soloing 10 of your dudes, but they also have to be in a large group?  There's nothing you can do other than cheese it with harpoon nests, play it like a base building simulator and hope you don't get bored by the time you get strong enough to engage in the content.  All the other NPC's are turtling also, some of the races have like 50+ or something NPC's all cluttered in a single town.  So attacking a single one will get you mobbed quickly.

I frequently travel to cities to collect "pre owned" merchandise and resell this to another village deeper into the forest. Good game/yes

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Kenshi as an idea has taken me in a way that most largely produced titles haven't been able to.  Having played just above 80 hours I feel I can write a decent review of this game.  Having bought the game almost a year and half ago and seeing short progress I was worried; however, it's good to see that there are dedicated people still out there not just trying to get their quick cash and move on.  Kenshi offers you a vast empty (which is good)  desert world where you must fend for yourself and that's as far as the story will take you at this moment in time.   The choice is yours, what do you do? Read a bunch of f**king guides is what you do, or at least myself, but I digress.  Throughout gameplay you must make decisions where to incoporate your time....as in...do I take my only 2 soldiers to escort my 3 traders to a town to sell Ale/chainmail/katanas/fragaxes/medkits/etc, or do i keep 1 soldier at the outpost guarding 2 of those traders while they continue to produce while only sending 1 soldier and 1 trader....which could possibly be attacked by a multitude of people (have fun with that population setting!)  At the same time you must research and dedicate certain squadmates to certain jobs where they will become more proficient as such.  Efficiency is key in Kenshi especially when you just start your outpost.          Base building is relatively smooth with only minor bugs which can be avoided by a quick save and reload  (applies to entire gameplay as well), and although there aren't uses for many of the items currently ingame besides monetary value there is much promise for the future.  The core buildings on the other hand are useful and there are many of them with industry like processes to advance your small faction as such.            As far as skills go Kenshi has many of the same skills you find in any other RPG game out there, the difference is that these skills actually have a real-time effect in gameplay.  What i mean by that is that if you have low strength, good luck carrying that backpack full of steel, wearing durable heavy armors, and larger weapons all while slowing you down becoming cannibal food in the process......AND making your Attack say (-14) because you dont know what you're doing with said weapon......fool.         So the game hits on the saying "practice makes perfect." in a nutshell in all skill-like aspects.  The unfortunate side is that there are still a considerable amount of skills "greyed" out not finished yet (awesome when finished)  but do not let that take away from this light of a game in this dark re-hashed titled clone world of ours.  It's EA and for as imperative as the devs made the skills (not just stat raises) is something fresh, oh what else is fresh that i forgot..LOCATIONAL DAMAGE!  wut, indie game? Naw that's unheard of...WRONG.  You get your leg beaten to a pulp?  Well I hope you can afford a walking stick Mr. Gimpy until you treat it medically.  The best part is that you don't die instantly, you bleed, you fight, pass out to wake and fight again! then pass out! and die.  Game over unless you have meds.           Visually, the game remains desolate yet somehow pleasing.  It actually feels like a post-apocalyptic world that you were just thrown into with the sole goal to survive however you see fit.  Some of the structures do look a little edgy at times, and not everything lines up 100% but the end result is fair enough.  Things look as they should....In conclusion, because I'm mediocre at reviews,  I find Kenshi very immersive, well thought and executed, and a challenging game considering the dev's choice of realism.  That's saying a lot for those indie's and with this one you'll dump hours into it without even realizing once you understand the concepts.  Honestly, I can't wait to play this thing once it's finished....seriously.  There's nothing else like it right now.  For how much this game costs and for how much content you get it's a decently fair price, try to get it on sale if you can.  Plus, I totally believe in supporting devs that change the industry with great ideas like this. Keep it up!Gameplay:    8/10Visuals:         7/10Updates:       6/10  (steadily increasing)Overall quality:    7/10Progress?   I'd say it's around 60% done overall (don't murder me it's an educated guess)P.S.  The bugs (not crashes) i've personally found to be more amusing than not most of the time.  Watching bandits and sometimes fellow squadmates violently ragdoll into the sky for a brief moment when are knocken unconcious can somewhat take me by surprise.  Or when the ai gets stupid and bunches up for a massive aoe 1 hitter with a frag axe. KO mother*****

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								As it stands now in Early Access, Kenshi shows a lot of promise as a hit game.  I play with experimental patches enabled, and I get to see the latest additions to the game- bugs included.  If you're a fan of participating in the course of a game's development, your input can- and will greatly impact- the course of the game's development.  This is one everyone should get onboard for!For starters, I'd like to thank members of the development team and their forum moderators for being so involved in discussion.  Many of the threads created in both the Steam forums and the Lo-Fi Game forums end up with answers from members of the team, and what you say can and will make an impact.  To be able to get in touch with someone heading up the game and recieve a personal response is both uplifting and noteworthy.  For me, this game gets high marks for this level of involvement in the community, as for many other development teams, such close coordination has been too much to ask for!On to gameplay; Kenshi is an interesting mesh of Real Time Strategy, base-building, caravaneer mechanics, where you have many choices of how to make your living.In terms of RTS, you can choose from or mod your own Game Start that allows you to pick a set of characters or character, and enter the game world to begin an adventure.  Mechanics are simple:  Using the Numpad or your mouse, you select your character and order them with a click to move.  You can do this to adjust your active navigation, taking detours where you need to, or you can rely upon the surprisingly competent pathfinding AI, which can take you from one side of the map to the other appropriately if you let it, though sometimes patches make this feature a bit fragile.  There is no first person or third person play, it's really a game of watching and hoping you've trained your guys enough that they can handle themselves in a combat situation.Your life revolves around your squad, and what you choose to do with them.  You will, at some point, be attacked, and you will have to fight back, so it's best to train up your brave men and women any way you can to keep yourself above the frey.  At lower levels, combat can be hard, if not embarassing.  You can be slaughtered and not even see a rational reason why (other than your guys just suck at swinging a weapon).  Currently, swordsmanship is the big deal going around, granted the namesake of Mortal Kombat character Kenshi (literally; swordsman), though turrets have been added to the game and ranged weapons are expected in the future (no muskets or revolvers, though modding will make that quite easy to do once ranged mechanics are in, so look forward to it!).The real fun in Kenshi is in what you decide to do with yourself once you're in.  Bounty Hunting, Raiding, Murder and Looting are all part of the possibilities, but more than that, you have the option to become the target of such things.One of the lifestyles you can fall into is a sort of wandering trader, or caravaneer.  Basically, you throw backpacks on a few of your squad members, put the best weapons in the hands of your best muscle, and send your people from town to town crating goods for sale.  Each town hosts a unique set of prices for certain goods; Chainmail can be worth 76% of it's base value one place, and 130% of that value in another, allowing you to invest a lot of money that makes a good return.  All that matters is that you don't oversell to the extent that it breaks their bank.  Being a traveling merchant grants many benefits, and it's a good way to get a leg up in a new game, as running builds strength and athletics, which aid in fighting, running and hauling later on in your lifecycle.Alternatively, the player can create their own town and have the merchants come to them.  Now, this is a fantastic feature, the construction mechanics of the game are pretty solid, even in it's current state.  If you see a man-made structure in the game, chances are that you'll be able to build it.  You start with a decent shack or house, build a research table, set up a farm, and start work on learning new things and stockpiling new resources.  It takes a while for a town to become self-sustaining, but when it does, you can feel free to hermit it up.  You basically have the same tools at your disposal as the developers do when it comes to construction, and you can make the same quality of layout if your talent allows.  Setting up shops and resource centers allows trade and storage, and building walls and turrets keeps out any unsavory individuals that you might find in the wasteland.  Yes, sometimes a world without borders can be a dangerous one.If being a nice guy minding his own business doesn't suit you, or if the Holy Nation stumbles upon your town of peaceful Shek peoples, becoming a more hostile force is also an option.  You even get the option to be a little creative...  Building cages and holding areas for the people you knock out on the battlefield gives you the option to take prisoners, and there'll certainly be more that you can do with this mechanic as the game progresses.  The Role Playing options offered in this game exceed those offered in many others, and the style of gameplay isn't just fun, but addictive.With this said, there are a few downsides to the game that you would probably want to know about before buying.For one, Kenshi seems to be set-in-stone in terms of what lore it will follow.  This is no problem to most people, but to some, it's pretty concentrated on one Apocalyptic Eastern theme.  I've found that the concept the game follows is a bit rigid, as it celebrates the way of Eastern warriors, yet, leaves out the opportunity to equip shields for added defense, neglects any Western-style weaponry (no Claymore, Gladius, Spear, or Cutlass styles), and the story behind it all can be a bit confusing, at times, with regard to finding a point in it all.What bugs me about the weapon variety is partly explained by the fact that I'm more familiar with Western swordsmanship than Eastern, and I feel that these arts are something that the game is missing out on in a great opportunity.  As it stands, there are a limited number of weapon classes and they're pretty much wide-spread, though manufactured by different "companies" and distributed across the world.  There's a lot of room for far more variety, and it'd help a lot to convey the differences in design between factions if these weapons weren't just different shaders and colors, or cousins basically (different but the same).  Don't get me wrong, there's like 12 separate weapon types in the game, but they're all pretty closely related.  If more varieties were included, you could see a stronger divide between each faction, and one sword from Holy Nation could convey an entirely different culture than a sword from the United Cities.  That's the biggest thing about this metal craftsmanship; it makes unique combat styles for unique cultures.  More weight should be placed in this category of diversity.The next thing is definitely the lack of shields.  Blocking is done by swords, and if you've studied metal, you know at some point it'll give out.  Eastern warfare did involve the usage of shields in battle at times, and they really do deserve a place in the combat dossier.  Additionally, including shields would open up a new realm of possibilies for modders possessing the talent to model new designs for inclusion in the game.  Imagine having an entire Roman Legion patrolling the game world, the possibilities are endless.When it comes to the background of Kenshi, I feel that it might be set in stone, and since I don't know what's written on that stone, it leaves me unsure of how the development will play out.  I am confident in the team's ability to carry out their mission and bring this game to completion, but I do worry that some ideas might not see the light of day.All said, this game is well worth buying!

content:
Posted: April 23
Early Access Review
								The freedom in this game is amazing, you can do everything you want.The combat system is one of the nicest of ever seen, but can be very frustrating at some point.Training of your characters is a long process of grinding teeth and smashing keyboard, as you will be losing nearly every fight you get into, and especially at the start it will force you to alot of screenstaring before you can play again, waiting for your guys to heal up.Every little mistake is punished brutally hard, some early mistakes will haunt you later on in the game, rushing things will get you in trouble, the game is very unforgiving, and at times you even wonder if the game is even any fun at all, as you will get annoyingly frustrated at nearly every aspect of the game.From graphics, to Ai pathfinding, to combat to building, everything has something that will annoy the hell out of you, top this off that the game will put your PC to its limits, since the game is badly optimized.I cannot recommend it in its current state, unless you are able to cope with frustrations well, and have the patience of a dead cat.Still the game is somehow dispite it all, kinda fun and addictive and unique.But it needs stil alot more time to evolve its gameplay, as half of the features are incomplete or even missing, and that what is in, all has issues/bugs to a certain point.The interface is a utter mess, and doesnt handle big number of NPC's, but the game is all about having alot of NPC's working for you, so here it shoots itself in its feet. The Ai is still WIP and will make you cuss and swear hard at times, even make you wonder if they ever will get this right, if that is in a game on this scale even possible.Still yet what they have done in this regard is remarkable, but it does make you wonder if they arent pushing it to far, and that its even possible Ai wise to every get this working perfectly.This is one of those games, that is pushing the bounderies of gaming, giving a unique game that cannot fully be compared to other like-wise games, mostly due its scale and size with absolute freedom.And its logical this comes with a price, and the price is a very... extreme long development time, so i play the game now and then, to a point where you really notice its pretty much WIP and trying to play it further just makes you hate the game too much.And still.... if you can deal with this all.. its one of the most original hardcore brutally hard games out there, with topics most other games dont even dare to touch, slavery, extemetism, narcotics, crime and even cannibalism and opression, its all there.And some factions will put your moral compass to the test, and uther loathing them for what they stand for.I never had such feelings in any other game for virtual factions, but in this game, i really have a deep hatred for some of the factions views and laws...This is a game that you want to see completed, but you prolly have to wait a very long time before its done.Very fitting for this game, as the gameplay is nearly as slow as its development.I recommend this game only to those who can deal with the game, its certainly not a mainstream game.IF you cannot deal with bugs, unpolished gameplay, long development time, and frustratingly hard gameplay, with every odd stacked against you, you will not like the game at all..

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Brilliant game. When I bought this game quite a long time ago I had originally thought the developers had bitten off more than they could chew as the sandbox feel, and being able to do almost anything you want with AI reacting accordingly seemed ambitious, but its coming together now and they are pulling it off as promised. There are still a lot of things that need to be fixed but so far I am having a blast and am glad I re-installed the game to give it another go.Build a massive town, recruit people to help you run it efficiently and have them setup for certain tasks so you dont have to micro manage them. Steal, kill, kidnap, do whatever you like to get ahead. Just be cautios of the reprocutions of your actions. There isn't to much of a story line that I have found, but that doesn't really matter as you are essentially creating your own story. It seems as if only a 1/4 of the world is done and can be explored, but its big enough to keep you busy for quite some time. Once the other 3/4 are done it will take you quite some time to thouroughly explore all that the world has to offer. Setup your town almost anywhere, just can't set it up to close to another town. It seems like there are well over 100 different things you can build in your town, and that is not including the massive amount of things you can craft. Setup a shop and sell your wares to passers by even. If you are into well thought out sandbox RPG style games, you wont be dissapointed unless you are not someone who can get over little quirks.The Devs seem to be throwing in updates way more often than I remember and I think that had something to do with them changing engines or re-writting things back in the day which held them up. I am hoping they can get to more content and features soon, but am satisfied at the pace they are going as of now.Right now my character has a $23,000 bounty on his head, is hated by half the map, and I am loving it. It makes it challenging and then doesn't make me feel bad when I sneak up, knock someone out stealthy, take their stuff and throw them in a cage.I must say this game is a buy, and once it has been completed I would pay at least 2.5 as much as what the game is selling at now. Nice Job Devs!

Early Access Review
								Kenshi Is a fantastic idea but is one of those gruesomely Beta/Alpha games that we all know steam to be a hub for. There is still alot of work to be done on stability (The experimental version is very prone to crashing) and aspects of the game are still in progress of being developed. So if you have a short temperament you may wish to wait till it's finished.That being said it's very difficult drawing yourself away for it. Creating your charaters from hair to feet then training them up in whatever respected fields you wish them to delve into from farming to swordplay to thievery . Beautifully thought out landscapes and structures to explore and the abusive bandits that wander there. Once you make enough of a living from selling your scraps to traders in towns, you can even build your own settlement from scrach and make a town of your own.Hopefully if and when the game is finished being fiddled with, this can be an amazing game giving players the full freedom every RPG deserves.

Early Access Review
								I love this game!I'd say Kenshi is a one of a kind, a bit of a niche game.. there are very few you can compare it to.The learning curve is steep, but the mountain top is not too high!Because it is a open world sandbox game you can play Kenshi in so many different waysEverything from being just a handful of very highly trained ninjas to a big warband of mercenaries, or perhaps you want to be a merchant, set up shop inside a city ? or build your very own city and bring trade to you!I have 140 hours on record all played with the same savegame and i consider myself having reached 'end game' if that term even applies to a game such as this :P and what I will say is there are end game features missing, such as proper diplomacy, ways of making your own actual faction/kingdom, waging war + the fact that only half the map is playable. So I feel like I am out of things to do on my current savegame because I am strong enough to assult cities and wiping them out, but it doesnt lead to alot currently..but trust me when I say the journey there was SO enjoyable I can't even.. and the devs do work on it and update it frequently adding in all these things that are missing!Very much reccomend this game!

Early Access Review
								Well..................I bought this at the end of Crimbo 2016 as the writeups were quite good and seemed like a challenge from what I was reading. + I was bored to tears.And.............in the space of 3 weeks I have racked up 146 hours!!!!!!!!!!!!! :-O I got over 300 on Fallout 4 for over 3 months playing it on and off, so this has been a real developer achievement to me!!!!Okay, so yes, it's ard! It's bloody ard to begin with but once you start realising that being beaten the s*it out of is actually good for you and that selling iron to shops for supplies until you can buy your first companions to speed up that process then go on to building a base and farms and producing weapons you can sell for huge profits instead of lumps of iron.........everything develops really fast and the exploring can commence!Pros: Base building including trading for food or developing your own farms and power systemsMicro management from the ground up (But not TOO much and can get 1 person taking up several jobs simultaneously)Fair and realistic levelling system for your troopsLive how you want to live: Be a thief, be a farming community, be a bandit community, be weapon/clothing/armour smiths or be all of that in one go as long as you dont pee too many people off as they dont forget (I was friendly with Holy Nation only until I knew my peeps were geting ard and could rip them new a** holes when demanding I follow their ridiculous religion every single time I went near their camps.....better not say much more......)Enjoy exploring a relatively huge map which is overwhelming to begin with, but feels small after sploring every corner looking for artifacts. < There is a shaded out part that is to come in the future and it's HUGE!!!!!Cons:Not optimised enough for anything under the "recommended" system requirements in my opinion and my rig is slightly better than those specs and still have to run this in low settings. (It's still beautiful though!)Annoying saving timesAnnoying loading timesSome infuriating glitches exist such as people becoming stuck and brainless but a long save and load cures this.It's got me hooked and I have a fully self sufficient town with 10 "Homesteads" (Farmers, smithys creating 6k garments and weapons, water collectors, miners etc etc) 10 "Warriors" who are only defeated in this game by Leviathans (You will see, but if you do manage to kill a "Baby" you get a very pricey artifact :-/) and finally, the "Legends"......erm....Hercules, Iolus, Xena, Gabriel and Maximus.....and they are still sh*te, ha ha ha ha. Oh and a massive "Elder" Mountain Dog I started with that tears everything apart like a rabid rhino, 3 bulls for trade caravanning which also ram attackers flying into the air or many meters away which is amusing, and a seriously leary Bonedog. Yeah.......this game is a great world to escape to.......and even cancelled a couple of real world adventures because of it in December.Highly recommended, and it's still under development with continuous and steady updates!Be aware though, if you are like me, you may start off and think OMG this is terrible and request a refund, but I followed the advice of other reviewers and gave it a couple of hours.....than BAM, glued like a ladys six toy to the clat.

								Kenshi Is a fantastic idea but is one of those gruesomely Beta/Alpha games that we all know steam to be a hub for. content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Brilliant game. When I bought this game quite a long time ago I had originally thought the developers had bitten off more than they could chew as the sandbox feel, and being able to do almost anything you want with AI reacting accordingly seemed ambitious, but its coming together now and they are pulling it off as promised. There are still a lot of things that need to be fixed but so far I am having a blast and am glad I re-installed the game to give it another go.Build a massive town, recruit people to help you run it efficiently and have them setup for certain tasks so you dont have to micro manage them. Steal, kill, kidnap, do whatever you like to get ahead. Just be cautios of the reprocutions of your actions. There isn't to much of a story line that I have found, but that doesn't really matter as you are essentially creating your own story. It seems as if only a 1/4 of the world is done and can be explored, but its big enough to keep you busy for quite some time. Once the other 3/4 are done it will take you quite some time to thouroughly explore all that the world has to offer. Setup your town almost anywhere, just can't set it up to close to another town. It seems like there are well over 100 different things you can build in your town, and that is not including the massive amount of things you can craft. Setup a shop and sell your wares to passers by even. If you are into well thought out sandbox RPG style games, you wont be dissapointed unless you are not someone who can get over little quirks.The Devs seem to be throwing in updates way more often than I remember and I think that had something to do with them changing engines or re-writting things back in the day which held them up. I am hoping they can get to more content and features soon, but am satisfied at the pace they are going as of now.Right now my character has a $23,000 bounty on his head, is hated by half the map, and I am loving it. It makes it challenging and then doesn't make me feel bad when I sneak up, knock someone out stealthy, take their stuff and throw them in a cage.I must say this game is a buy, and once it has been completed I would pay at least 2.5 as much as what the game is selling at now. Nice Job Devs!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23
Early Access Review
								The freedom in this game is amazing, you can do everything you want.The combat system is one of the nicest of ever seen, but can be very frustrating at some point.Training of your characters is a long process of grinding teeth and smashing keyboard, as you will be losing nearly every fight you get into, and especially at the start it will force you to alot of screenstaring before you can play again, waiting for your guys to heal up.Every little mistake is punished brutally hard, some early mistakes will haunt you later on in the game, rushing things will get you in trouble, the game is very unforgiving, and at times you even wonder if the game is even any fun at all, as you will get annoyingly frustrated at nearly every aspect of the game.From graphics, to Ai pathfinding, to combat to building, everything has something that will annoy the hell out of you, top this off that the game will put your PC to its limits, since the game is badly optimized.I cannot recommend it in its current state, unless you are able to cope with frustrations well, and have the patience of a dead cat.Still the game is somehow dispite it all, kinda fun and addictive and unique.But it needs stil alot more time to evolve its gameplay, as half of the features are incomplete or even missing, and that what is in, all has issues/bugs to a certain point.The interface is a utter mess, and doesnt handle big number of NPC's, but the game is all about having alot of NPC's working for you, so here it shoots itself in its feet. The Ai is still WIP and will make you cuss and swear hard at times, even make you wonder if they ever will get this right, if that is in a game on this scale even possible.Still yet what they have done in this regard is remarkable, but it does make you wonder if they arent pushing it to far, and that its even possible Ai wise to every get this working perfectly.This is one of those games, that is pushing the bounderies of gaming, giving a unique game that cannot fully be compared to other like-wise games, mostly due its scale and size with absolute freedom.And its logical this comes with a price, and the price is a very... extreme long development time, so i play the game now and then, to a point where you really notice its pretty much WIP and trying to play it further just makes you hate the game too much.And still.... if you can deal with this all.. its one of the most original hardcore brutally hard games out there, with topics most other games dont even dare to touch, slavery, extemetism, narcotics, crime and even cannibalism and opression, its all there.And some factions will put your moral compass to the test, and uther loathing them for what they stand for.I never had such feelings in any other game for virtual factions, but in this game, i really have a deep hatred for some of the factions views and laws...This is a game that you want to see completed, but you prolly have to wait a very long time before its done.Very fitting for this game, as the gameplay is nearly as slow as its development.I recommend this game only to those who can deal with the game, its certainly not a mainstream game.IF you cannot deal with bugs, unpolished gameplay, long development time, and frustratingly hard gameplay, with every odd stacked against you, you will not like the game at all..

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Of course trhere need a lot to be done.. On the other side: this is a realy great game with a lot more potential for the future! Worth to buy and play it now allready; in my opinion YES !!! With the start as 'wanderer' you have to do it all the way, and this is very nice to play. My first money i spend on good boots and an extra backpack, with a bit luck i found 2 dead body's and take there cloths & weapons.. so good enough to equip at the moment.. Then i found a group of bandids, i run back towards the city i started and let them killed by the guards there.. did enjoy the battle myself also, and making progress in attack & defend that way. With all those loot i found on there body's ik make nice money and could hire the first 2 members of my group..Did this a couple times and could hire 2 more (already trained) other members + better gear. Start to get building on my self.. started with my 1st settlement with a little barack and a stone mine.. Now after +- 30 hrs playing time i have 8 members (3 last recruited in the second city i visite), upgrade the stone mine, build also 2 power-generators, a stone working machine, build the 1st house with 4 beds and training body + first city walls build to protect my 1st settlement a bit and.. All members well equiped for there level. Some little inside story's.. : After several fights with smaller bandit-groups (i can take them down) and bigger groups of sand-bandits (witch i take after me to the city-guards, to fight them together and take there loots.. + selling the gang-boss for good money to the head guards).. ..then there came a group of 'cannibals'.. to my little settlement.. they take 2 of my members down, picked them up and running away with them.. omg.. lol.. bud, they run into the arms of a walking patrouille from guild guards.. they take the cannibals down and my members could struggeled back to our settlement... pffftttt.. end good :P In all the time i played till now, i only have 2 crashes (saving regulary is always the better thing to do), so that's not so bad for a starting game i suppose. There is a well done balance between the attacks from the (4 differend types) of bandids walking around and the time you can spend on selling, buying, training, building).. That's very satisfied to play like this in a game like this!Conclusion: Like i say at the beginning, there is still a lot to do.. but for sure it's worth to buy and play! For now allready nice playing and we hope it will be more and more in the future.. All by all; Thanks to the maker(s) : nice & good work allready, hope a lot more to come.. Have fun by playing this xD

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								I bought this game early Alpha on steam and from then up until now i have not once regretted that decision, I have played countless hours of the game and every time i pick it up to play/start a new game i find myself locked into the world of Kenshi for countless hours without realising just how much i need to get away from my PC. Since Beta the amount of content added has been amazing, the game has progressively gotten better without breaking away from what makes the game gorgeous. The game is immense in terms of how you can play it and what you can do within it, the quality of the content is in no way lacking and neither is the replayability because of it. Starting as a lone wanderer and deciding to build a town or village from which to build your own trade empire has such a wonderful feel to it as you slowly watch as your carefully maintained entourage survive and grow stronger. The only reason i cannot give this game 5 stars is because the game is of course in early access and thus prone to bugs, of which I have experienced none, and constant change. I find it exciting as more get's added, starting fresh never feels boring as every new game can be played wildly differently and watching my main character grow stronger, and with the combat your successfull battles actually feel thoroughly fulfilling, never seems to grow tiresome. I highly reccomend this game, it is not like most top down Sim/Rpg ish game's are and it's definitely tough to get a handle on at first but twice as rewarding once you start to understand the hidden beauty behind this game. Even down to the music and plentiful subtleties that can be found within the game, i found the experience and continued experience of playing this game to be unchangingly pleasant. Most definitely worth far more than they are asking for price wise.

								Kenshi Is one of my favorite games of all time. The free roam combined with the ability to play however you please is great. The sword fighting is smooth and feels like a action movie. content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game provides all the elements I look for in a game if any of the following apply to you, you will enjoy this.1. Micromanagement; As your group grows the functions for each grow and multi tasking stays fresh, you wont go long before a bandit attack. There's always work to do, training to be done the tasks never end. Making your party run laps in their precious down time, training your combat skills on captured prisoners, producing gear or buildind/researching the list goes on.2.RPG; Each character has its own stats, the time it takes to get anything to level 20+ is abit time consuming, but it gives a sense of satisfaction as you make another character a mighty warrior in the wasteland.3.City Building; Build your own city! it takes time, but building your own utopia complete with shops, workshops, homes, outposts, defense walls, mounted crossbows, the only limit is how long your willing to spend preparing your characters for the coming construction.4.Crafting; At first its more about gathering gear from fallen foe's outside the city gates, but once you begin teching and producing your own gear, a high quality katana compared to a rusty one is a beautiful sight, you can also produce all the raw materials needed for self preservation which is tougher, but for some more rewarding.5.Diplomacy; Want to be friends with a certain group of bandits? Heal some of their fallen kin, eventually they will stop attacking you and come to your aide. (This takes time, I also assume in the future there will be many diplomatic aspects, but have yet to be added).6.Permanent Death; Think your starter character is a badass? wrong. Each unit becomes precious, you grow attatched as they become valueable, and then at the worst moment a critical strike leaves them stranded far from a safe location, too far to carry safely without a character with strength above 30... you keep watching hoping the bleeding stops and he'll enter a recovery coma but no his status switches to "dying" and you panic, time to decide if your capable enough to make the rescue, because even if you are, a large enough band of bandits/cannibals could strike you all down, and end your game. (Also note, the cannibals will take your people prisoner and amount of time you have to wait for a distraction is FOREVER, but its great).7.Travel/Relocation; Making it town to town in the begining is thrilling, as your group grows and you safely reach each destination, perhaps traveling with a caravan or a squad of UC/HO troops for safety, or braving the journey alone it's deadly every time. Also, the town you're in could be overrun. (I've seen it happen twice lol)8.Huge Replay Value; Start in a new town, new conditions, different starting squad, death at the start, who knows? The randomness is astounding, you could find "wingman" at the start, walk out near "Shark" and get hacked to piece by roaming sand ninja. You've read enough. Buy it, before it gets better and you feel like an idiot for not have gotten it sooner.

content:

Early Access Review
								I played this game for over a year on Desura before it came to Steam and let me just say, if you're looking for a fun tactical-strategy-rpg-citybuilding extravaganza, look no further. Kenshi has the most open playability of any game I've played since Ultima Online. If you want to develop a trading outpost into a bustling town, you can. If you just want to be a bunch of nomad bandits, have at it!Pros-Such Depth! Much Fun!-Deep Character Progression-Develop your faction into whatever you want from honored to infamous and enjoy the faction effects it has toward every other group in the game.-Awesome Music, but it gets a little repetitive after hours.-Fun Crafting and Construction System!Cons-There's a bit of a learning curve and -Unrealistic combat. The best way to grind skills is to walk fights and just kite the enemies to a town to level up your fighting which gets monotonous and doesn't make any sense. Were I a bandit, I doubt I would chase some nobodies to my doom, but that's just me.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								GOD I want to love this game. I really want to. I've played over 40 hours in an absurdly short amount of time trying to love it and make it work. I know it just went Beta, but this is one of the least playabe Betas (or even Alphas) I have ever taken part in.Pathfinding is absolutely terrible. The worst of any RTS I've ever played. If you build a wall, plan on randomly getting stuck on terrain and having to deconstruct part of the wall so your resources are *poof* gone. Oh it's not over there - good luck trying to get the two parts of the walls to attach again, because there is random wall collision detection that prevents you from attaching the two pieces of the wall, so there's a good chance you'll have to start over on a huge section of wall. There have been modest improvements to pathfinding, not least of which is your squad tries its best to use the road rather than going offroad. This seems to be a hasty workaround, because going offroad seems to get you stuck for no apparent reason a lot of the time. Also plan on reversing your path and straightening out an approach on one squad member when going through gates into cities. The devs have the best intentions by attempting the following:- Auto-hauling- Priority queues- Clicking on a point on the map and having the squad automatically go thereThe problem with these is the execution. Auto-hauling works alright, but you have to have a specific box for the item. For example, autohauling stone has to go to a stone box. So you're taking up a ton of space with storage boxes. This leads into priority queues, which only show 5 of the tasks you have lined up even though you can have more. So if you have 10 resources you want to haul to 10 different boxes for efficiency's sake, you won't see the 5 tasks in the bottom of the queue so you have no idea if you actually have them queued or not. So you might have to deleted and restart your entire queue if you forget.When going to a city by selecting a point on the map, there's a good chance your squad will randomly stop and just stand there because it doesn't know where to go, even though you selected a point on the map. This map feature is very new, so I'll give it a pass. It just needs some polish. It works a lot of the time.Whoamygod crashes. Pre .90, crashes used to be once every 5-10 minutes (so lower your Autosave threshold unless you want to constantly lose progress). Patch .90.11 made the game literally unplayable (crash shortly after load every time, regardless of whether you start a new game or not).  However, since then the crashes have gotten LOADS better. I just hope this continues.The devs try hard (it seems) but it feels like they're playing a game of whack-a-mole. They squash a bug, another bug (or two, or three) appears in its place. I just hope to god it gets a lot more polish in the automation and pathfinding departments. Micromanaging to this degree and especially with this much frustration is not fun. If these key areas improve, this will turn a messy, bug-ridden game into a GREAT game.All that ugliness aside... I will continue to support the game (because it's the only one of its kind really right?) and will likely change my review if there's a lot of polish. Right now it's not lookin good though.

								I have played this game since version .15 or so, back when it was nothing but a desert and black portraits for characters. Having said this, the game has come a long way since then. However, after the version that added the first new expansion to the north of the new map the additions are trivial and "same old" as the ones that came before them. While some bugs have came and gone no actual meaningful features have been added just new areas to do the same old things in.I've played this game on multiple different saves, some with huge squads, some with just 4, and on steam here this many hours was put solely on a single character. I mention this because playing with a single character will allow you to see the overglaring flaws that this game has fundementally. I loved Kenshi, when the first map expansion came out and I ran into the armor king I couldn't wait for chris to add more depth to the story or even special characters like him but I've been let down every single update since then as I said previously any new expansion is just additions to the same old routine. At this point in my solo playthrough I can kill anything without much effort, even being hopelessly outnumbered. Most of the main draw of the game *was* the difficulty for me, that has now been shattered. It took over 100 hours to get to that point but the fact it exists and any new content is null because of it shows that this game will not be anything more than it is currently. It lacks depth it lacks character. Even if they throw the rest of the map together I'll just roam aimlessly to find all markers and slaughter the highest stat enemies I can find but none of it will bring the fun back.You can steal things, why bother after the 2nd or 3rd town sack? You can kill things, why bother after 80+ stats, you can trade, why bother when you don't even need cats unless you need material from shops. That is the current feature list as it stands. You cannot meddle within the current factions, you cannot influence them in any way, you cannot help them against eachother in any way. In short, the only decisions you have to make seem rather dull and tiny compared to when you let your imagination run free and fill in the gaps for you. There's no doubt that anyone who first loves this game as I have will do that very thing. In the end it comes down to this; Is Kenshi worth 20$ as it stands? Yes, it is. even playing as I did, 100 hours is easily worth the money, I've spent far more on far less gametime. But do I recommend it to others? No, it's a love-hate relationship for me. Once you see the game for what it really is it's a shell of what could have been. I can only imagine how chris will decide to salvage what tiny bit is left to finish and tie it all together. Unless he's hiding some major features that he has yet to even announce to anyone after all these years the game core itself, the very heart of it, will be a cheap experience that will continue to make you feel empty and ask "what if" or "what could have been"

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								One of the hidden gems of steam, this rare greenlight success story stands as proof that amongs the sea of greenlit garbage, there still exist some quality titles.I would urge anyone who has been scarred by the early-access system not to be afraid. I've owned this game since 2013 back when there were only ~three types of armor with similar graphics and few features of note. It somehow managed to be surprisingly fun then, and it has only gotten better since. The dev('s) put out updates often and the game has undergone fundamental changes since 2013. The squad system, the new worldmap, the new factions, the overhaul of equiptment (eg. the armour I mentioned earlier) - all these things have changed since then and every one of these changes, though I often initially missed the old ways, were for the better.Some will say a sandbox game which has been in early access alpha for two years is neccesarily a lost hope. This game proves otherwise.The game is still a little laggy and may run slow on older rigs, it also occasionally crashes, though the rate of these has fallen drastically since '13.I strongly reccomend this game to anyone interested in a vast, open-world survival RPG where it is the player who creates his/her own story.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								Adventure, survival, RPG, we’ve all seen it before; no matter how many times a game promises that you will forge your own adventure, there seems to be only one effective way to play and one ultimate end where you have max-stats and all the rarest weapons. What if there was a game where you actually had options and could have your own adventure, where there are so many ways of getting through every challenge you face and so many ways to recover from such that in simply travelling from one town to another can end up with you making lasting fun memories and maybe some lasting great enemies?Like that time I was heading though a desert valley, got spotted by wild dogs who started to chase me, I ran as fast as I could and ducked into a shack at the nearby farm. The Dogs were distracted by the cattle which they attacked and brought down. The farmer and his family came out to try and fend off the dogs, I ran out to help but we were overrun as more dogs came. We were all knocked out from our wounds in the battle, I awoke later and did what I could to bandage myself and the dying farmer’s family but it was no use, the dogs came back almost immediately so I retreated to the shack and closed the door. When all was said and done I was the only survivor, I collected what supplies I could and snuck away as cautiously as possible. To this day the farm is a ghost town with an eerie lack of life, shrouded in the memory of that fateful day…Yes this game has bugs, the AI pathing is ludicrous and optimization is questionable, there are many features that are missing and seem to create holes in gameplay but never-the-less in its current state it is still bar none the best roleplay and best adventure game I have ever seen. There’s potential around every bend and every time you close out the game it’s a cliff hanger you just can’t wait to see resolved, if you are looking for an adventure game where the decisions you make don’t just put you closer to an ultimate end but rather shape your character and the world around you alike, then this game is well worth the $20…

content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Saw this game featured in recommendations for several of my favorite games and some i have been following the development of for a while. I decided to give it a shot after reading comments on the atmosphere and music. Once installed i was quickly transported to a world of desperation and brutality. The learning curve is a bit intense, but the freedom granted by getting the gist of the smallest game functions grants enough reward that i think it could appeal to a fairly large portion of the gaming community.  As mentioned in other reviews, there is no story, there is no goal, and there is no point to survival other than those goals that you set for yourself. There is a potentially high true roleplay factor generated by the simple fact that each sect has its own set of rules and laws, You can either conform or reject, you can fight or flee, you can walk a fine line or separate yourself from "society" completely. Any play style can reap its own set of rewards and the replayability factor is very high.The negatives seem to all be the typical early access flaws, mainly in fine tuning a few lag issues, some buggy behavior in the town generation every so often (two builds of mine so far produced nothing but destroyed/abandoned towns and farms). There have been a few strange bugs involving theft and whatnot but nothing unmanageable or repeating on reload. If you are a fan of open world games, and NWN style squad based games, Use based skill leveling, base building etc... give this a shot. I don't have any regrets with the current price and am looking forward to being done with this review so i can play some more.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you liked the challenge of dark souls; the strategy elements of an RTS, and the sandbox open world of minecraft, then this is for you...Though still in  Early Access, This is perhaps one of the best games I have ever played.Cast into a post-apocolyptic  world with no explanation, you quickly find yourself outnumbered and overpowered...by every enemy you encounter.You will quickly realise that you are not privilaged, you don't miraculously have "1337 5KI11Z". You earn every bit of what you accomplish; through blood, sweat, and tears.But then, the day that you finally stand up for yourself and beat those bandits, all by yourself, you feel the most overpowering sense of accomplishmentYou will travel mostly aimlessly through the huge desert (And I mean HUGE, it takes ages to get to the other side of the map even on 4x speed), picking up a few followers here and there.Eventually you will build a town, and learn to defend it, as you research more and more technologies, the game completely sucking you in.after several IRL days,(or weeks, depending how often you play),you will eventually find yourself with amazing custom forged weapons and armour, an undefeatable army, and automated mining systems. and your still only halfway through the game....However the game IS still in early gameplay, and as such features a few humerous (and annoying) errors that will leave you grinding your teeth in frustration; but if you are prepared to deal with a little annoyance for a lot of reward, this game is for you.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11
Early Access Review
								Where to begin ?I've bought kenshi loving the kind of universe it offers (samurai, desert and post apocalypse, count me in just for the heck of it), and the promises it makes.Even though it still is in beta and is expected not to deliver on all aspects a game this ambitious takes into account, Kenshi does a fantastic job so far.I will go through a somewhat thorough description, so if you want all my pros and cons, just skip ahead to the pros and cons at the end of my review1) It is absolutely gorgeous, all in all, environments and biomes are fantastic to wander in and discover. Also your characters can be created beautiful or ugly, straight or broken, and all the same believable. You can also zoom in or out insanely, pause your game, rotate your camera around at any time, and watching your character paused while delivering a huge knee hit at any view angle, kicking asses and taking names is somewhat exilarating considering how hard the game is whe you begin with the "rock bottom" background.2) The game is also very challenging even when you know its mecanics. It doesn't hold your hand, lets you be taken into slavery,  and I discovered to my great demise the hardship of having women squad members in the holy nation territory  . For once (save for the demon souls / dark souls series) a game is truly unforgiving, and at the same time really rewarding. The areas you couldn't get to before because of their inherent hardship hold many secrets and loots, the first one being the discovery of the world itself (yes, it is that beautiful and engaging) , trying to make the history of the world out of the lore, the stories you hear or read, or even a faction name.3) The map (as far as version 0.95.11 goes) is HUMONGOUS, and it is even not half of the final intended map. I can't wait to get my mitts on the next piece of it. Con for a map this size so far is that it feels a bit empty for now, but if you go to the kenshi trello, you can see that there are still many improvements to come, (which I won't cover here, go check it for yourself) and that this game is destined to get fuller and fuller as updates come to be.4) Squad management is rewarding, as well, and you can easily specialize squads in all the different gameplays the game can offer, from brutal combats with consequences to day-to-day hunger, items creation, trading management. The downside is that you also feel sometimes a bit limited in this "lite strategy game" mecanic (and as a caesar 3 or AoE 2 fan, I easily want more of it, even though it is not this game's objective) .5) You can create anything, as long as you get your hands on the recipe or blueprint.  So Hell Yeah Edge Type Weapons . Con not all blueprints available, and the artifact system feels sometimes restraining. For now. 'Cuz the map is not yet complete The artifact system : each playthrough you get to have with each new update you decide to play and import a previous play onto lets you have a different experience than the previous one : you get all the same locations, but not all the same items. 6) consequences of your acts are true, and I feel somewhat happy when I break the previous bounty record on one of my characters head  including the Bugmaster's .PROS : - So far so good, it has taken me more than a hundred hours (and many more to come with each upcoming updates)- Total Freedom of action- HUGE map- Many factions- you create your own story- continuous open world- The Squad system and its management- Impressive and complex gameplay mecanics and intense close combat system- A world with consequences (to a certain extent, the world itself is a consequence of a previous catastrophe)- Gorgeous and sexy- You make your own story- many items- there is always a solution to your problem- unforgiving- Early access (it is so complete so far that you still feel you're playing a complete game with free DLCs coming up every now and then)CONS:- Early access (you feel sometimes frustrated with the absence of things yet to come)- The map is so huge it feels sometimes empty (yet to hell with that, it is supposed to be a sarce wasteland and a freaking desert)- You can't truly choose a faction, or become its boss, safe for your own, and opposite faction are not enough of a threat past a certain point.- Still a lack of lore, quests, and multiple Choices story scripts (but I guess in a game this complete, it will come last)- no claustrophobic dungeons with ancient freakin' horrors and freakin' loot inside- No (or not yet) freakin' large army and combat system- there is always a solution to your problem- not enough items considered it is a world with a past rich enough to have robots roaming the wastes- not unforgiving enough past a certain point (at some point every character becomes a bit overkill, can take down complete ennemy squads, and the lack of diplomacy makes the consequences less of a challenge since the factions get so weak)

content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you liked the challenge of dark souls; the strategy elements of an RTS, and the sandbox open world of minecraft, then this is for you...Though still in  Early Access, This is perhaps one of the best games I have ever played.Cast into a post-apocolyptic  world with no explanation, you quickly find yourself outnumbered and overpowered...by every enemy you encounter.You will quickly realise that you are not privilaged, you don't miraculously have "1337 5KI11Z". You earn every bit of what you accomplish; through blood, sweat, and tears.But then, the day that you finally stand up for yourself and beat those bandits, all by yourself, you feel the most overpowering sense of accomplishmentYou will travel mostly aimlessly through the huge desert (And I mean HUGE, it takes ages to get to the other side of the map even on 4x speed), picking up a few followers here and there.Eventually you will build a town, and learn to defend it, as you research more and more technologies, the game completely sucking you in.after several IRL days,(or weeks, depending how often you play),you will eventually find yourself with amazing custom forged weapons and armour, an undefeatable army, and automated mining systems. and your still only halfway through the game....However the game IS still in early gameplay, and as such features a few humerous (and annoying) errors that will leave you grinding your teeth in frustration; but if you are prepared to deal with a little annoyance for a lot of reward, this game is for you.
